content: “Can anyone imagine The Lord’s Prayer recited in a classroom?” Founder and President Martin Mawyer said in a statement on CAN’s website. “Or students taught that the Bible is the inspired, infallible final Word of God? Or displaying the Christian cross in the school classroom? Or lesson plans that encourage students to pray to Jesus Christ? It’s out of the question! Christ, the Bible, the cross and Christian prayer were thrown out our public schools decades ago.” OK, let’s go through these points one at a time. First, the Lord’s Prayer is a prayer. Nobody is asking students to pray any Muslim prayers. Second, nobody is being taught that the Quran is the infallible final Word of God delivered by the Messenger Angel Gabriel (which is what Muslims believe). The Quran is merely being presented as the holy book Muslims use as the base of their faith and the guide for their lives. Third, nobody is demanding that Muslim symbols be displayed in classrooms at all, let alone as an endorsement of a religion as prohibited by the First Amendment. Fourth, students are not being required to pray as Muslims do. This isn’t about prayer. It isn’t about proselytism. It’s not about converting children to Islam. It’s about understanding the mindset of the second-largest religious group on the planet. All of Mawyer’s points have to do not with educating anyone about a particular religion, but about evangelism and converting people to Christianity. And that has no place in a public school classroom. Just as converting people to Islam or any other religion doesn’t belong there. But that’s not what this is.
